#Text=Prepare for Knee Arthroscopy Surgery ( Teens )
#Text=When teens have to have knee surgery , they often need to have an arthroscopy .
#Text=An arthroscopy is a surgical procedure that uses a small camera and small instruments to see inside a joint ( the knee in this case ) and fix any problems .
#Text=( It 's Latin , arthro meaning " joint " , and scopy meaning " see inside " ) .

column1: #Text=A knee arthroscopy is one of the most common surgical procedures , even for teens .
#Text=Steps
#Text=As Soon as Possible
#Text=Find out what your pre-op instructions are .
#Text=You might have to stop taking medications such as NSAIDs up to two weeks before your surgery .
#Text=You will also want to know how long before your procedure you must fast .
#Text=It is often from midnight the night before surgery on , but there are exceptions , so be sure to go over this with your surgeon .
#Text=Find out what you may need to get ready for post-op .

#Text=This may include a brace/immobilizer , an ice machine/ice packs , pillows and blankets for comfort in the car on the way home from the hospital , or a prescription for pain meds ( some surgeons will give you the prescription ahead of time , others will only give it on the day of surgery ) .
#Text=Gather all the items that you find out you need from the previous step .
#Text=Take time off work/school if needed .
#Text=If you are in school , try to get your homework ahead of time so you can do it before your surgery .

#Text=If you ca n't do this for one reason or another ( such as surgery being booked for the next day , it does happen ) , try to email your teachers at least , and this way they will hopefully give you an extension on the work being done on your surgery day , and potentially for a few days after your surgery ( in case you need to stay out of town overnight , or are in too much pain to go back the day after ) .
#Text=If needed , book a hotel .

#Text=Especially in rural areas , there may not be an orthopaedic surgeon in your town/city , so you may have to stay in a hotel before and/or after your surgery , especially if you need to have a drain removed the morning after surgery .
#Text=Make sure to ask for a medical rate , as many hotels offer discounts for medical appointment-related stays .
#Text=One Week Before Surgery
#Text=Make sure you know all of your pre-op instructions .
#Text=If you are to discontinue the use of some medications , this is especially important .
#Text=You also need to know when to stop eating and drinking the night before surgery .
#Text=Ensure you have all of the post op supplies discussed above .
#Text=The Night Before Surgery
#Text=Eat a good dinner , and have a big snack , along with lots to drink .
#Text=You wo n't be able to eat or drink after midnight ( with exceptions ) on this night , so make sure you are well-fed , and well-hydrated .
#Text=Make sure you follow your NPO , or Nil Per Oral instructions .
#Text=This means no food or drink after a set time , usually midnight .
#Text=Should you not follow your NPO directions , you may not be able to have your procedure done .
#Text=Have everything ready for the next morning , such as clothes , toiletries , entertainment etc.
#Text=Get a good night 's sleep .
#Text=Even though you will be " sleeping " with the anaesthesia the next day , you do n't get rest with anaesthesia , so you still need to get a good sleep .
#Text=The Day of Surgery
#Text=Stay NPO .
#Text=This is for your safety , as you do n't want to choke on your stomach contents while under general anaesthesia .
#Text=Remember , if you eat or drink , your surgery may be cancelled .
#Text=Wear loose , comfy clothes .

#Text=It helps to wear short , baggy shorts , or loose pyjama-type bottoms , as if you need a drain after surgery , this will make it easy to get your bottoms over the drain , and also the bulky dressing that will be on your knee after surgery .
#Text=You may also have a knee immobilizer , which , again , is quite bulky .
#Text=Make sure you show up on time .
#Text=If you do n't , you will have to wait even longer to get your knee fixed .
#Text=Be ready to wait .
#Text=Bring entertainment such as a phone or tablet , so you have something to do while you wait .
#Text=Prepare yourself for discomfort .
#Text=After surgery , you will fell very tired , hungry and thirsty , and maybe a bit nauseous .
#Text=You will also likely be in quite a bit of pain , and you may have a drain in your knee to drain excess blood and fluid from your knee .
#Text=This will be removed about 18-36 hours after your surgery .
#Text=Make sure you follow any and all post-op instructions , such a as physiotherapy , weight-bearing restrictions and bracing/wrapping .
#Text=Your surgeon should tell you or your parents all of this information .
#Text=Tips
#Text=You may not sleep much the night after your surgery , as you may be in quite a bit of pain .
#Text=This is a good night to stay up and watch TV !
#Text=If possible , ice your knee after surgery .
#Text=Not only will the cold help with swelling , but also with pain .
#Text=An automatic icing machine , or " cryocuff " , while expensive , can be a worthwhile investment to simplify the post-op icing process .
#Text=If you 're prescribed pain medication , take it on schedule , even if you are not in pain .
#Text=It is better to be “ ahead ” of the pain than try to “ catch up ” .
#Text=After a few days , you will want to start weaning off the prescription medication and onto an over the counter drug , such as Advil or Tylenol .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=You may not be able to use all the timing suggestions in this article , sometimes you are only given a few days to prepare .
#Text=You can still use all the information , just in a different time frame .
